description: GRANTS- The United States currently has two defense needs for domestically mined uranium: low-enriched uranium to produce tritium for nuclear weapons, and highly-enriched uranium to fuel nuclear reactors in Navy submarines and aircraft carriers. The U.S. Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration has sufficient stockpiles of...
text:
GRANTS - The United States currently has two defense needs for domestically
mined uranium: low-enriched uranium to produce tritium for nuclear weapons,
and highly-enriched uranium to fuel nuclear reactors in Navy submarines and
aircraft carriers.

The U.S. Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration has
sufficient stockpiles of unobligated uranium to support tritium production
until 2041 and Navy fuel until the 2050s, according to the U.S. Nuclear Fuel
Working Group, established in 2019 by President Donald Trump.

With uranium supplies available to meet the country's needs for the next two
to three decades, why would the Working Group recommend creating a second
uranium reserve?

"The coronavirus pandemic has reminded us that foreign nations do not
necessarily have America's best interests in mind," Energy Secretary Dan
Brouillette wrote in a May 28 letter regarding what must be done to revive
America's nuclear energy industry and restore the United States' competitive
advantage.

The country's long-term ability to build new nuclear warheads and fuel its
submarines and aircraft carriers depends on the domestic production of
uranium, as civil nuclear-cooperation agreements prevent foreign suppliers
from providing the element for military purposes, he said.

Creating a reserve

The Working Group strategy calls for funding advanced research, development,
and deployment of America's next generation of nuclear energy technologies to
ensure the country's long-term global competitiveness and maintain its non-
proliferation leadership.

"From health care to energy, the global battle for supremacy and influence
continues unabated. If we are to remain a safe, secure, and prosperous country
in an increasingly hostile world, we must take these important steps to
protect Americans at home and our interests abroad," Brouillette wrote.

The Strategy to Restore American Nuclear Energy Leadership, a report released
in April by the Working Group, and the President's Fiscal Year 2021 Budget
Request, published in February, propose establishing a uranium reserve for the
United States to "provide additional assurances of availability of uranium in
the event of a market disruption."

It is expected that the reserve would directly support the operation of at
least two U.S. uranium mines and the reestablishment of active domestic
conversion capabilities.

Energy Fuels Inc.'s White Mesa Mill near Blanding, Utah, produces two minerals
on the U.S. government's list of minerals deemed critical to national and
economic security  uranium and vanadium. As the country's top uranium
producer, having overtaken Cameco, Energy Fuels is hoping to have an active
role in supplying the new uranium reserve.

Next giant leap'

In addition to energy and defense applications for uranium on Earth, as part
of a broader strategy to regain American global leadership in nuclear energy,
the Department of Energy is leading efforts with the private sector to promote
the development and deployment of small modular reactors and microreactors
with its sights set on the "final frontier."

Those reactor technologies could be modified to provide sustainable power
sources for space applications such as surface power and nuclear thermal
propulsion. DOE already is working with colleagues at NASA and the Department
of Defense on applications of those technologies, Brouillette stated in
remarks to the National Space Council May 19.

Under the new lunar exploration program "Artemis," named in 2019 for the
goddess of the Moon and twin sister of Apollo, NASA will send new science
instruments and technology demonstrations to study the Moon, accelerate plans
to send astronauts to the Moon by 2024, and establish sustainable lunar
exploration by 2028.

DOE has been meeting regularly with colleagues at NASA "to better align space
program activities to support America's return to the Moon, its next giant
leap to Mars, and its future beyond," Brouillette said.

"In particular, we are partnering with NASA to demonstrate nuclear thermal
propulsion and surface fission reactors, which will support power requirements
for crew transportation to the Moon and eventually Mars, as well as help power
our envisioned outposts there," Brouillette said.

"With nuclear propulsion, we can potentially cut the time of space travel to
Mars by half, while offering increased mission flexibility," he said.

keywords.text: next generation of nuclear energy technologies

title: Need for domestic uranium stretches from Earth to Mars
html:
GRANTS - The United States currently has two defense needs for domestically mined uranium: low-enriched uranium to produce tritium for nuclear weapons, and highly-enriched uranium to fuel nuclear reactors in Navy submarines and aircraft carriers.

The U.S. Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration has sufficient stockpiles of unobligated uranium to support tritium production until 2041 and Navy fuel until the 2050s, according to the U.S. Nuclear Fuel Working Group, established in 2019 by President Donald Trump.

With uranium supplies available to meet the country's needs for the next two to three decades, why would the Working Group recommend creating a second uranium reserve?

"The coronavirus pandemic has reminded us that foreign nations do not necessarily have America's best interests in mind," Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette wrote in a May 28 letter regarding what must be done to revive America's nuclear energy industry and restore the United States' competitive advantage.

The country's long-term ability to build new nuclear warheads and fuel its submarines and aircraft carriers depends on the domestic production of uranium, as civil nuclear-cooperation agreements prevent foreign suppliers from providing the element for military purposes, he said.

Creating a reserve

The Working Group strategy calls for funding advanced research, development, and deployment of America's next generation of nuclear energy technologies to ensure the country's long-term global competitiveness and maintain its non-proliferation leadership.

"From health care to energy, the global battle for supremacy and influence continues unabated. If we are to remain a safe, secure, and prosperous country in an increasingly hostile world, we must take these important steps to protect Americans at home and our interests abroad," Brouillette wrote.

The Strategy to Restore American Nuclear Energy Leadership, a report released in April by the Working Group, and the President's Fiscal Year 2021 Budget Request, published in February, propose establishing a uranium reserve for the United States to "provide additional assurances of availability of uranium in the event of a market disruption."

It is expected that the reserve would directly support the operation of at least two U.S. uranium mines and the reestablishment of active domestic conversion capabilities.

Energy Fuels Inc.'s White Mesa Mill near Blanding, Utah, produces two minerals on the U.S. government's list of minerals deemed critical to national and economic security – uranium and vanadium. As the country's top uranium producer, having overtaken Cameco, Energy Fuels is hoping to have an active role in supplying the new uranium reserve.

‘Next giant leap'

In addition to energy and defense applications for uranium on Earth, as part of a broader strategy to regain American global leadership in nuclear energy, the Department of Energy is leading efforts with the private sector to promote the development and deployment of small modular reactors and microreactors with its sights set on the "final frontier."

Those reactor technologies could be modified to provide sustainable power sources for space applications such as surface power and nuclear thermal propulsion. DOE already is working with colleagues at NASA and the Department of Defense on applications of those technologies, Brouillette stated in remarks to the National Space Council May 19.

Under the new lunar exploration program "Artemis," named in 2019 for the goddess of the Moon and twin sister of Apollo, NASA will send new science instruments and technology demonstrations to study the Moon, accelerate plans to send astronauts to the Moon by 2024, and establish sustainable lunar exploration by 2028.

DOE has been meeting regularly with colleagues at NASA "to better align space program activities to support America's return to the Moon, its next giant leap to Mars, and its future beyond," Brouillette said.

"In particular, we are partnering with NASA to demonstrate nuclear thermal propulsion and surface fission reactors, which will support power requirements for crew transportation to the Moon and eventually Mars, as well as help power our envisioned outposts there," Brouillette said.

"With nuclear propulsion, we can potentially cut the time of space travel to Mars by half, while offering increased mission flexibility," he said.
